title.rendered: New Logo and Identity for The Parent House by Brand Union

content.rendered:
Established in 2000, The Parent House is a charity in Islington, a district in Greater London that is well documented for its levels of poverty and low income houses. Its goal is to reduce child poverty in the borough by empowering parents through education, providing one-to-one support, offering a handful of practical courses, and mentoring over the course of six months. Earlier this year, The Parent House introduced a new identity designed by the London office of Brand Union.

We simplified and opened up the logo in line with the charity’s pledge to provide open-door support for its parents. Our key element is the frame. Flexible and multiform, it acts like a photo frame to hold treasured memories, whether image or text. It preserves real moments in time, marking pivotal turning points in parents’ lives, and it’s evocation of the home reflects the familial atmosphere of a charity in which many parents return as members of staff.

Brand Union provided text

Given the, um, less than stellar presence of the old logo — although the knob on the crossbar of the “H” is a glimmer of good intentions — it would be easy to do anything better and that’s basically what Brand Union has done: take it easy. The new logo is nice and simple and it has a quick, clear read about what it is. I like that it combines the image of a house with that of a book opening or closing even though they refer to it as a picture frame, which makes the concept a little too sentimental. The typography is fairly bland and even though it’s technically centered, the arrangement doesn’t look centered.

In application, the logo and system could have been elevated with a little more work on it. Everything feels like a first pass. The business cards could not be any more basic and the icons lack so much consistency — thick lines! thin lines! thinner lines! — that they would be better off without. Other than using the same rounded sans serif in every size, there is really nothing bringing this together in an interesting manner. I would assume this was done pro-bono and given the effort Brand Union has made on (also assuming) well-paying gigs like Absolut Flavors that turned out fantastic, this feels pieced together as quickly as possible to free up billable hours. Overall, the work is fine and perfectly functioning, most likely a million times better than the materials The Parent House had before but it could have been a million and one. It’s that little extra that makes a difference. And that’s what’s missing here.
